title: How to Compress Images Online: Reduce File Size Without Losing Quality
content:

- Support for JPG, PNG, and WebP formats
- Browser-based processing for complete privacy

## What is Image Compression?

Image compression reduces the file size of images by removing unnecessary data or using efficient encoding methods. There are two main types:

### Lossy Compression

Removes some image data permanently to achieve smaller file sizes. Best for photographs where minor quality loss is imperceptible.

### Lossless Compression

Reduces file size without removing any image data. The original image can be perfectly reconstructed. Best for graphics, logos, and images needing perfect fidelity.

## Step-by-Step Guide

- **Low (60%)**: Maximum compression, noticeable quality reduction
- **Medium (75%)**: Good balance for most uses
- **High (85%)**: Minimal quality loss, good compression
- **Best (95%)**: Near-original quality, moderate compression

### Step 3: Optional Size Limit

Set a maximum width to resize while compressing, achieving even smaller file sizes.

### Step 4: Compress and Download

Click Compress Image to process. Review the before/after comparison and download your optimized image.

## Best Practices and Tips

### Finding the Right Quality Level

1. Start with 85% quality for most images
2. Check the preview for any visible artifacts
3. Lower quality if more compression is needed
4. Test on different devices before final use

### Format Selection

- **JPG**: Best for photographs, use 75-85% quality
- **PNG**: Best for graphics with transparency, use PNG-8 for simple images
- **WebP**: Best overall compression, use for modern web browsers

### Workflow Tips

- Compress images as the final step before publishing
- Keep original uncompressed files as backups
- Use batch compression for multiple images
- Combine with resizing for maximum file size reduction

### Web Performance Goals

| Image Type | Target Size |
|------------|-------------|
| Hero/Banner | Under 200KB |
| Blog Images | Under 100KB |
| Thumbnails | Under 30KB |
| Icons | Under 10KB |

## Understanding Compression Results

### What Affects Compression?

- **Image Content**: Photos with many details compress differently than simple graphics
- **Original Format**: Already compressed images have less room for optimization
- **Color Depth**: Images with fewer colors compress better
- **Image Size**: Larger dimensions mean larger files

| PNG (photo) | 60-80% |
| Camera Raw | 80-95% |
| Already Optimized | 10-20% |

## Frequently Asked Questions

### How much can I compress an image?

Typically, you can reduce file size by 50-90% depending on the original image and quality settings. Photographs with high detail compress less than simple graphics.

### Will compression ruin my image quality?

With proper settings, compression is virtually unnoticeable. At 80-85% quality, most viewers cannot distinguish compressed from original images.

### Should I compress PNG or convert to JPG?

For photographs, converting PNG to JPG and compressing gives better results. Keep PNG for images requiring transparency or with text/graphics.

### What quality setting should I use for my website?

For web images, 75-85% quality typically provides the best balance. Hero images may need 85-90% while thumbnails can use 60-70%.

### Can I compress images for print?

For print, use higher quality settings (90-95%) to preserve detail. Print typically requires higher resolution than screen display.

### Why is my compressed file larger than expected?

Some already-optimized images have little room for further compression. Converting formats (like PNG to WebP) may help achieve better results.
